seem.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: if something seems to be true, there are things that make people think it is true
seem.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: It seems a foolish decision now.
The last few days had seemed like a dream.
Teri seemed like a nice girl.
We waited for what seemed like hours.
It seems like you’re catching a cold, Taylor.
It seemed as if the end of the world had come.
It seemed that Freeman had killed the man, and dumped the body in the lake.
It seems likely that he will miss the team’s next game.
The rainbow seemed to end on the hillside.
Doesn’t that seem weird to you?
It seems to me you don’t have much choice.
There seem to be a lot of people outside.
seem.translation[0].definitions[0].note_: In written English, people often prefer to use appear rather than seem, because it is more formal:
It appears that the man had been murdered.
seem.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: used to make what you are saying less strong or certain, and more polite
seem.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: I seem to have lost my car keys.
It would seem that someone left the building unlocked.
seem.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0]: Seem is a linking verb This type of verb links the subject of the sentence with an adjective or noun
She seemed satisfied with his explanation
seem.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1]: Seem is not used in the progressive You say
seem.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: These reports appear to be unfounded.
to seem to be something, often because of what can be seen
used to say that something or someone seems to be something because of what you have heard or read about them, or because of the noise or voice that you hear
They heard what sounded like a blow.
to seem to have particular qualities
He comes across as a very sensitive man.
